24.40.text: First in the spotlight tonight is the Emmerdale actor Liam Fox.

27.88.text: His specialist subject - Auf Wiedersehen, Pet.

36.88.text: The comedian Nick Helm answers questions on Alice Cooper.

43.00.text: And the actress Kimberley Nixon on Agatha Christie's Poirot novels.

60.36.text: Hello, and welcome to Celebrity Mastermind with me,

63.56.text: John Humphrys, and four people who may at this stage be wondering

67.40.text: why they said yes to being here tonight.

69.96.text: Risking their reputations in the hope of becoming a Celebrity Mastermind.

75.04.text: They don't get a fee, it goes to charity.

77.48.text: But they do get the chance of winning a glass trophy and the title.

81.04.text: And to do it they get 90 seconds of questions on their special subject,

84.48.text: and then two minutes on general knowledge.

86.60.text: So let's get on with it and ask our first contender to join us please.

619.08.text: after the conductor brings him a glass of water BEEP

628.80.text: Kimberley, full house. You got 11 points.

639.28.text: Well, it couldn't be much closer than that.

641.56.text: Let's have a look at all the scores.

643.24.text: In fourth place, 7 points, Jon-Allan Butterworth.

659.44.text: And if there is a tie at the end of it, then the number of passes

662.44.text: is taken into account and the person with the fewer passes is the winner.

665.76.text: Let's get on with it and ask Jon-Allan to join us again please.

672.12.text: I know you lost your arm when you were blown up serving in Iraq.

676.56.text: What I find really hard to believe is that you became a phenomenal

680.48.text: cyclist and you had never ridden a bike without

684.32.text: stabilisers in your life before. Is that right?

687.04.text: Yes. It surprised me, to be honest, yeah.

689.32.text: And from when I started cycling to competing,

692.12.text: it was less than two years.

693.64.text: And London was three and a half years from taking it up to winning.

697.04.text:
- Yeah. 
- You had only three and a half years to prepare for the Olympics?

700.44.text:
- From when I started cycling, yeah. 
- From when you started cycling? 
- Yeah.

703.56.text: Exactly. And how come you realised, or who realised and how,

707.40.text: that you were going to be a brilliant cyclist?

710.00.text: I did a talent day at Loughborough University with Paralympics GB.

713.60.text: And I got identified there as having potential talent.

716.96.text: I had a choice of one sport to choose from cos

719.00.text: I was rubbish at everything else.

720.60.text: So it all worked out well in the end.

722.44.text: But cycling you can manage without any trouble?

725.76.text: It still comes with its challenges, you know?

728.36.text: Obviously 70K around the track with one arm is quite scary at times.

731.48.text:
- Trying to handle a bike. 
- Quite!

733.48.text: But I can compete with some of the best cyclists

735.68.text: in the country so I'm happy with that.

977.20.text: He never went, but a lot of his mates did.

979.56.text: So watching that programme kind of reflected my dad's life

984.40.text: It was very apt and very on the ball and very real at the time.

1168.04.text:

1173.44.text: I just write the songs on Uncle.

1176.60.text: But I do stand up and I do music with my stand-up

1179.36.text: and I find that quite good.

1180.76.text: Cos you have a five-minute chunk where you don't actually have to

1183.56.text: be funny. You can just make a lot of noise and that takes care of itself.

1187.20.text: Presumably, it's got to be quite nice noise?

1189.80.text: Well, if you finish a song people generally clap at the end of it

1192.96.text: and you feel like you've achieved something. So that's good.

1195.60.text: Oh. What, they clap even if it's rubbish?

1197.88.text: Yeah, tends to be. It's great.

1199.80.text: And actually, if we go back a bit,

1216.52.text:
- That's true.

1224.80.text: you should just draw on all the things that you can do

1227.04.text: to a certain standard and then just put it all in.

1229.64.text: I do a bit of everything to keep people

1231.96.text: distracted from the fact that it's all fairly rubbish.

1417.16.text: I don't know. I can only say why I like them.

1422.56.text: The Mysterious Affair At Styles, was in 1920.

1425.28.text: And the last Poirot book was 1975.

1435.76.text: Everything gets wrapped up and everything gets taken care of.

- Yes.
